Description: Forepart of terracotta figure of elephant. A front fragment of a figure of a tusked elephant standing on a low plinth, the skin shown by a series of striations. The body is lost from behind the ears and front legs, and the end of the trunk is broken away. Hollow; apparently made in a two-piece mould, but the panel between the front legs may have been applied separately. Orange-red clay, probably a Nile silt but not certainly so, with some mica. Red-brown slip overall.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Bibliog. Pococke 1743: 213, pl. lxiv:H, who misunderstood it completely, comparing it with a wadjet eye.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3740)
Condition: Body lost behind ears and front legs, end of trunk broken.
